{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3182488,"name":"Ian McTavish","username":"Ian_McTavish","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/b5a626/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-06T23:34:20.780Z","cooked":"

We are looking at replacing our stock of canbus wire. Currently debating using 22AWG (seems to be the standard for CTRE) with 20 AWG. We use Wago 221 side by side connectors and found we could break the 22 Awg wire from Vex when we pull on it. We borrowed some 22awg from another team and could not break it.
Any recommendations would be appreciated. Canadian suppliers preferred!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-06T23:34:20.780Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":295,"reads":542,"readers_count":541,"score":1578.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Ian McTavish","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17356,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3182514,"name":"Nicholas ","username":"unident","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unident/{size}/188354_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T00:41:03.341Z","cooked":"

Can wires shouldnt be subject to that much force, but it would be nicer to have a more robust cable than the typical 22awg. as to why your VEX wire broke and the undefined other brand didnt, im not sure. if you make the change however, let us know how everything goes. not sure much will change, but if you notice any increase/decreasem post about it

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-07T00:41:03.341Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":524,"readers_count":523,"score":109.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Nicholas ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182551,"name":"Smtopps","username":"Smtopps","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/smtopps/{size}/166758_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T02:20:09.622Z","cooked":"

Update:

We ran two competitions with the current wiring setup without any can issues I can remember. At our championships we have had I want to say 4-5 of our matches today where canbus cables have broke out of the wago 221 connectors.

A few lessons (mostly wago connector related):

  1. The wago connectors have a sort of blade which on small wires can cut into the fine stands
  2. Never use smaller then 22awg wires with wagos if force may get applied to the connector.
  3. We did pull tests with 24awg in a wago and it broke. The 22awg vex wire also broke. The mystery 22awg held up great.
  4. Strain relief should help keep the wire from breaking. Our hypothesis is that there is a slight amount of force being applied as we move around is causing the wires to be slowly cut and it chose now along with hard impacts from defense to fail.

Were you using ferrules?

No we tried once and just ran into lots of issue with them coming out. Also it’s not really the intended use with wagos. We are looking at tinning the end of the wires though.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-07T02:29:56.283Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":398,"readers_count":397,"score":134.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Smtopps","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52551,"username":"andej","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ccd318/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33408,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182577,"name":"JRumple","username":"JRumple","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/f05b48/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T03:09:03.078Z","cooked":"
Smtopps:

Strain relief should help keep the wire from breaking.

Always use Strain Relief about an inch or two from all connectors. Also use staking on the wires so forces and vibrations don’t work towards the connectors.

The FTC Robot Wiring Guide (https://www.firstinspires.org/sites/default/files/uploads/resource_library/ftc/robot-wiring-guide.pdf) has a ton of other recommendations that FRC teams would do well to consider.

CAN has been used in the automotive industry for decades. I recommend looking into their wires and connectors as well as their best practices. Talk to the auto shop teacher at your school or an auto mechanic in your community. You will learn a ton from them. (Hint: There is a better topology than daisy-chain.)

As others have stated, the wires should be strain-releived so that there is never any tension on them

Smtopps:

we tried once and just ran into lots of issue with them coming out.

Where did you purchase your ferrules from?

We use cheap lever nuts from any one of the no name brands on Amazon for a lot of CAN and low amp power (https://www.amazon.com/GKEEMARS-Splicing-Connectors-Assortment-Connector/dp/B08QMLSMC6) with ~0.5" stripped wire shoved into it and we’ve never had one come out. And some have been under some tension without any strain relief.

If you go the tinning route make sure to have a good protocol for the student to follow, as over tinning can lead to more problems then it would fix.

JRumple:

(Hint: There is a better topology than daisy-chain.)

While there are easier to route topologies, I would not use them without extensive testing. I use this document as a reference: https://www.ti.com/lit/pdf/SLLA270

To OP: I’ve seen more wiring failures this year than any other year. At this point I’m ready to hot glue and ziptie literally every single connection on the robot right before a competition. We basically did as much at Idaho.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-07T15:25:03.676Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":86.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.ti.com/lit/pdf/SLLA270","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":27}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182749,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T15:26:31.251Z","cooked":"
Smtopps:

We are looking at tinning the end of the wires though.

In general, tinning wires going into various mechanical connections is not a great way to go. It changes how the wire is tightened into the connector and can loosen over time as the soft solder deforms.

The best bet is to follow the mfgr recommendations. Many of the connectors we use are designed to work on bare wire, not tinned, and not even really excessively twisted. I love ferrules as much as the next person for preventing stray strands from ruining my day but in reality, they aren’t the best way to go with a lot of the spring-loaded connectors we see in things like the PDP and PDH or in optional things like the Wagos. If the mfgr reccs bare wire, it’s probably the best bet for contact area, retention ability, and current carrying capacity (important for the bigger connections that are power rather than signal).

There is more to wire than just gauge; the number of strands can make a big difference. In smaller wire, you could easily see 7 or so strands of copper as well as 20+ strands of very fine wire. This impacts not just the flexibility for the wire but how well it might work in a specific type of termination.

Folks like Wago in this discussion take this stuff really seriously (knock off connectors - who knows?). They tell you what works best.

You can find different wire styles to match the connectors as well as avoiding problematic combinations.

You’ve already seen some direct evidence of a few different wires, same gauge, probably different strand counts, and how it can make an obvious difference so you’re onto something already.

Most of the connectors in FRC, including the ones on the PDH, accept ferruled wires as well as bare. Finding a good ferrule crimper is of greater concern.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-07T15:32:45.663Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":211,"readers_count":210,"score":47.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40142,"username":"zog","name":"Chris Herzog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182771,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T16:41:45.888Z","cooked":"
asid61:

Most of the connectors in FRC, including the ones on the PDH, accept ferruled wires

You’re right, the PDH Wagos are expressly rated for bare and insulated ferrules but without any specs on what a “good” ferruled connection is. I thought I had read the Wagos in the PDP really were spec’d for bare wires but can’t seem to find that reference right now.

The Wago 221 series don’t call out a ferrule as a connection but do support solid, stranded, and finer stranded as termination options; there are different gauge limits when using solid wire with these connectors.

The cheapy Amazon ferrules most of us use sort and indeterminate quality crimpers readily available online sort of give me the heeby-jeebies (though I swallow hard and use them at times). There are ferrules from Weidmuller, Panduit, Phoenix Contact, and TE Connectivity (and others). It’s clear there are good and cheapy crimp connectors so maybe I’ll pick some of these up and compare them against the typical Amazon-sourced assortments most of us probably use.

What do you consider a “good” ferrule crimper? I’ve got some of the 4 and 6-sided Iwiss models and I’m sort of ambivalent on their results. Knipex makes some if you want to stand tall but at $220+, that’s standing real tall. I’ve got about that much into my ratcheting crimpers when including dies so I’m not opposed but that’s getting pretty rich.

Knipex also makes a $35 crimper that is sort of pliers style (https://www.amazon.com/KNIPEX-97-62-145-Crimping/dp/B005EXP6MU) but it’s only good for 24-14ga. What’s interesting is rather than the square crimps a lot of the tools make (those using the 4 distinct spring loaded crimping “fingers” - there are 6-sided ferrule crimpers as well) , this makes a very distinct trapezoidal crimp which means there is almost certainly a preferred orientation when putting into a connector.

EDIT: the Weimuller 9012500000 ferrule crimper does a trapezoidal crimp as well with the serrations below the “long” side of the crimp - interesting…

What do recc as far as crimpers and ferrules?

[ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182789,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T16:59:36.421Z","cooked":"
zog:

It’s clear there are good and cheapy crimp connectors so maybe I’ll pick some of these up and compare them against the typical Amazon-sourced assortments most of us probably use.

The biggest limitation is a good ferrule tool. Finding one that’s decent under $100 is very difficult. The Iwiss ones are anywhere from serviceable to actively junking the connection. So far I have had good luck with this Weidmuller one but nothing cheaper. That $35 one from Knipex is very interesting. I might give that a try the next time I need to make a ferrule crimper purchase. I don’t see a need to ferrule anything under 20AWG anyway, as the larger power wires are easier to strain relief and rarely pull out.

I like using any branded ferrule, with a preference for Panduit (no particular reason).

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2023-04-07T16:59:36.421Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":191,"readers_count":190,"score":48.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":433242,"topic_slug":"canbus-wires","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/weidm%C3%BCller/9005990000/492957","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/canbus-wires/433242/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3182824,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-04-07T17:52:13.953Z","cooked":"
asid61:

So far I have had good luck with this Weidmuller one but nothing cheaper.

That looks interesting.

It looks like it crimps from the end as opposed to side, right?

I’m assuming it does the trapezoid shaped crimp as the die shape is described as “trapeze”. Have you found a preferred insertion orientation to be important on the FRC conns we tend to see? I’m figuring long side up or down are the only two reasonable orientations.

I’m going to grab the Knipex for sure. I mean it’s $35 bucks, I’ve spent more than that numerous crimpers now floating in my drawer of “you’re dead to me” crimping tools

The right tool and connectors make all the difference.

Thanks for your thoughts.

Ok just before I go to bed. Wiring seem quite solid now but yes to much solder will cause it to come off. Our issue now is still related to canbus but different.

On our canivore which controls our drivetrain we are able so get the canbus to flash red when the steering motor rotates quickly but it produces no error on the driverstation and it doesn’t seem to cause any issues.

Testing in our pit we were able to cause the canbus to stop working when we hit something hard. Our best guess is the usb cable (on the rio side) to the canivore is still delivering power but losses coms with the rio. We also replaced the cable but that didn’t help. We have now hot glued it in. When it disconnected we lost drive and had lots of can errors on the driverstation. Canbus status lights were fine though. Repluging the usb reconnected the canivore and we can see it thought Pheonix tuner but none of the can devices showed up and the errors continued.

Since we glued the cable in we were able to drive the robot into solid things very hard and haven’t had it disconnect. The occasional red light on the canbus loop appears but caused no driverstation errors or anything weird.

Also earlier the canbus was all flashing red in the pit and we were getting driverstation errors but we could still drive it and receive encoder and gyro feedback.
